bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Walter D. McCaw, April 18, 1924

div1.p: Kean informs McCaw that Hendrick has agreed to publish his rebuttal to Marie Gorgas' article.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Walter D. McCaw, April 18, 1924
div1.opener:
Boston Mass
18 April 1924.
JRK/FM
Brig. Gen. W. D. McCaw,
Surgeon General's Office, U.S. Army,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Willie:
div1.p:
The Chief wrote me that he intended to go to Panama if
the appropriation bills in Congress made good progress. I hardly
imagine that that condition has been fulfilled, but as I see your
signature as Acting Surgeon General on a paper which came into
the office yesterday, I think he must have gone.

I returned to General Ireland, two or three days ago,
my criticism of the article in the World's Work by Mrs. Gorgas
and Mr. Hendrick with a letter from Mr. Hendrick which I thought
would not be satisfactory to Mrs. Reed and asked him to take steps
to have my criticism published. In today's mail comes another
letter from Mr. Hendrick which is much more satisfactory in that
he agrees to publish the correction. If my letter is on the
Chief's desk, please open it, read it and then put this with it.
If, however, he has not gone to Panama, please hand him this
letter.

The Kean family is going out of town to spend Easter
with General and Mrs. Edwards. There are very few signs of
spring here yet. A few Chinese magnolias are in bloom and the
buds of some of the horse-chestnut trees are making a showing
of yellowish green. With best wishes,
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, J. R. Kean Incl.
